definition: Consists of two continuous cavities: the abdominal cavity and the pelvic cavity.
The process by which substances are taken up into cells or tissues.
Having a pH less than 7; high in hydrogen ion concentration.
The movement of molecules across a cell membrane from a region of lower concentration to a region of higher concentration, requiring energy.
A substance that increases the hydrogen ion concentration in a solution.
A substance that cannot be broken down into simpler substances by chemical means.
A scientist who studies the structure of organisms and their parts.
Negatively charged ions.
A process of programmed cell death.
A molecule that carries energy within cells for metabolism.
The basic unit of a chemical element.
Having a pH greater than 7; low in hydrogen ion concentration.
The level of acidity or alkalinity in the blood, typically ranging from 7.35 to 7.45.
Positively charged ions.
Proteins located on the cell surface involved in binding with other cells or the extracellular matrix.
The study of the properties of substances and the changes they undergo.
Hair-like structures that extend from the surface of many animal cells and are involved in movement or sensory functions.
The fluid component inside cells, excluding the organelles.
A chemical reaction in which a single compound breaks down into two or more simpler products.
A protein that has lost its shape and function due to heat or other factors.
A muscle that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominopelvic cavity.
Farther from the point of attachment or origin.
Pertaining to the back or posterior side of the body.
Deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that carries genetic information in all living organisms.
Substances that dissociate into ions in solution and acquire the capacity to conduct electricity.
Negatively charged particles that orbit the nucleus of an atom.
Pertaining to the upper middle region of the abdomen.
A chemical reaction in which parts of two compounds are exchanged to form two new compounds.
The process by which waste products are removed from the body.
The process of spontaneous passive transport of molecules or ions across a biological membrane via specific transmembrane proteins.
The region of the thigh.
Tail-like structures that propel cells, such as sperm, in a whip-like motion.
A model that describes the structure of cell membranes as a mosaic of components that give the membrane a fluid character.
A simple sugar (monosaccharide) found in many plants, where it is often bonded to glucose to form the disaccharide sucrose.
A simple sugar that is an important energy source in living organisms.
An organelle involved in the modification, packaging, and transport of proteins.
The maintenance of a stable internal environment in an organism.
A chemical element with the symbol H and atomic number 1.
A weak bond between two molecules resulting from an electrostatic attraction between a proton in one molecule and an electronegative atom in the other.
A positively charged ion (H+), often formed when an acid dissociates in water.
Negatively charged ions (OHâˆ’) formed when a base dissociates in water.
A solution that has a higher concentration of solutes compared to another solution, causing water to leave the cell.
Pertaining to the region of the abdomen just below the ribs.
Pertaining to the lower middle region of the abdomen.
A solution that has a lower concentration of solutes compared to another solution, causing water to enter the cell.
Molecules that do not contain carbon-hydrogen bonds.
Proteins embedded within the lipid bilayer of a cell membrane.
Provides a protective barrier for the body and aids in production of vitamin D; eliminates some waste; contains sensory receptors for pain, touch, and temperature.
A chemical bond formed between two ions with opposite charges.
A solution with the same solute concentration as another solution, causing no net movement of water.
A group of organic compounds that are fatty acids or their derivatives and are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents.
The process by which simple sugars are converted to fatty acids and stored as fat.
An organelle that contains digestive enzymes and breaks down waste materials and cellular debris.
Anything that has mass and takes up space.
A type of cell division that results in four daughter cells each with half the number of chromosomes of the parent cell, as in the production of gametes.
The chemical reactions that occur within a living organism to maintain life.
An organelle responsible for energy production within a cell.
A process of cell division that results in two identical daughter cells.
The simplest form of carbohydrates, consisting of a single sugar molecule such as glucose or fructose.
Sodium chloride, also known as table salt.
Processes that reverse a change in a controlled condition to maintain homeostasis.
Subatomic particles found in the nucleus of an atom that have no electrical charge.
A type of covalent bond in which electrons are shared equally between two atoms.
The pressure required to stop the flow of water across a selectively permeable membrane.
Inflammation of the pancreas.
The outer layer of the pericardium, which surrounds the heart.
The outer layer of the pleura that lines the walls of the thoracic cavity.
Proteins that are located on the outer or inner surface of the lipid bilayer but are not embedded in it.
The process by which a cell engulfs particles such as bacteria or other foreign matter.
A type of lipid molecule that is a major component of the cell membrane.
The double layer of phospholipids that makes up the cell membrane.
A scale used to specify the acidity or basicity of an aqueous solution.
A scientist who studies the functions and mechanisms in living organisms.
A type of covalent bond in which electrons are shared unequally, resulting in a molecule with a slight electrical dipole moment.
The region behind the knee.
Processes that amplify a change in a controlled condition, often leading to a specific outcome.
Positively charged subatomic particles found in the nucleus of an atom.
Closer to the point of attachment or origin.
Atoms that have an unstable nucleus and release radiation as they decay to a stable form.
A protein that binds to specific molecules outside the cell, triggering a response within the cell.
A process by which cells absorb molecules by engulfing them, using receptor proteins to select specific substances.
The ability to sense and react to stimuli.
Cell structures responsible for protein synthesis.
Studded with ribosomes and involved in protein synthesis and modification.
A property of cell membranes that allows some substances to pass through, while others cannot.
The movement of molecules from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration without the need for energy.
Involved in lipid synthesis and detoxification of chemicals within the cell.
A disaccharide composed of glucose and fructose; commonly known as table sugar.
A chemical reaction in which two or more simple substances combine to form a more complex substance.
Sodium ion, which is positively charged due to the loss of one electron.
Near the surface of the body.
Above or higher in position.

term: The basic unit of structure and function
definition: The cell.
The central and most important part of a cell, containing the genetic material.
A space enclosed by the ribs, sternum, and vertebral column. It contains the pericardial cavity and two pleural cavities.
Groups of cells that work together to perform a specific function.
A type of fat (lipid) found in your blood that your body uses for energy.
Pertaining to the front or anterior side of the body.
The inner layer of the pericardium that covers the surface of the heart.
The inner layer of the pleura that covers the lungs.
A polar molecule essential for life, composed of hydrogen and oxygen (H2O).

term: Why is there such variation in size and shape of cells
definition: The variation in size and shape allows cells to perform different functions more efficiently.
A system of muscles that enables movement of the body and helps maintain posture.
A substance that decreases the hydrogen ion concentration in a solution.
Structures made up of tissues that perform specific functions in an organism.
Groups of organs that work together to perform a complex function.

term: Help to maintain the life of an individual organism
definition: A characteristic of organ systems working together to support essential functions of life.
Lower in position, or closer to the feet.
Molecules containing carbon and hydrogen, often associated with living organisms.
A chemical bond that involves the sharing of electron pairs between atoms.
A chemical bond formed between two ions with opposite charges.
The basic unit of carbon, an essential element in organic molecules.
A chemical element essential for cellular respiration and the production of energy in organisms.
A chemical element that is a key component of amino acids and nucleic acids.
Having a pH greater than 7; basic.
A scale used to specify the acidity or basicity of a solution, ranging from 0 to 14.
A group of organic molecules that are hydrophobic, including fats, oils, and waxes.
Organic compounds made of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen, which provide energy.
The building blocks of proteins, composed of an amino group, carboxyl group, and side chain.
Organic molecules that are insoluble in water and include fats and oils.
Complex molecules made of amino acids that perform various functions in living organisms.
Proteins that are embedded within the cell membrane, often involved in transport.
Small membrane-bound sacs that transport substances within a cell.
A cellular structure that synthesizes proteins.
The gradual difference in concentration of solutes in a solution between two regions.
A portion of the genome that encodes for specific proteins or traits.
